1.11.text:
So I was teaching this morning and one of
my students asked me

7.82.text:
What do you call the fingers in English?
And quite a good question

13.76.text:
So here's a video
So first of all this is your thumb

21.85.text:
Well, it's not your thumb
It's my thumb

26.05.text:
Some people say that thumbs are not fingers
I really don't know if that's the case or

31.73.text:
not
Anyway, what can you do with your thumb?

34.14.text:
Well, you can give someone or something the
thumbs up

38.18.text:
Just the same way as you do on Facebook
And the next finger is this one

44.73.text:
This is your index finger
Well, again it's not your index finger

48.85.text:
It's my index finger
But I think you understand that now

52.57.text:
index finger literally means
Pointing finger

54.94.text:
And I remember that when I was a little boy
at school we used to call this your pointing

60.64.text:
finger
Just because you can point at or point to

65.36.text:
things or people
Your index finger's quite a good finger

68.60.text:
There's a lot you can do with it
You can poke someone

72.50.text:
Last week my nephew Tomás poked me in the
eye by mistake

77.60.text:
It was quite painful
You can also poke people on Facebook

84.05.text:
Here's my dad
Let's poke him

87.16.text:
See if he pokes me back
I bet he doesn't

92.13.text:
Also you can press buttons with this finger
And of course this finger is the perfect finger

98.44.text:
for picking your nose
And when picking your nose if you find anything

103.34.text:
interesting you can flick it at a friend
The next finger is your middle finger

112.43.text:
And this is the perfect finger for insulting
people

116.29.text:
You give someone the finger
In the United Kingdom and in Ireland there's

122.34.text:
another way of insulting people with your
fingers and it's this

126.22.text:
This is me giving the v-sign
It's not as strong as giving the finger

133.67.text:
But you should be aware of it especially if
you visit the United Kingdom and Ireland

137.17.text:
If you are for example in a cafe in London
and the waiter asks you how many coffees you

143.18.text:
would like and you say two then you might
get in a fight

148.78.text:
On the other hand
On the same hand actually

152.17.text:
This is completely different
Making the v-sign is an international gesture

157.37.text:
and it probably won't get you into a fight
So apart from insulting people with your middle

162.80.text:
finger there's not really much that you can
do with it

166.09.text:
You can use it in combination with your thumb
to snap your fingers like that

171.82.text:
Now this finger is called your ring finger
I can't think of much you can do with it

176.99.text:
It's called your ring finger because in western
cultures if you're married you generally wear

183.66.text:
a wedding ring on this finger - your ring
finger on your left hand

189.57.text:
And finally this is your little finger
Sometimes it's called your pinkie

195.18.text:
I've got no idea why
Something interesting

199.32.text:
Well, it's maybe not very interesting but
it's something personal here that I'll share

205.24.text:
with you
My pinkies are not the same length

210.19.text:
That's because I broke this pinkie when I
was skiing in Edinburgh on an artificial ski

220.04.text:
What about that?
It doesn't really cause me any problems

224.06.text:
Sometimes when I'm walking down the street
people stop to stare and they point at me

230.10.text:
But you know
Anyway, one of the cool things about fingers

233.90.text:
is that they're strongly associated with a
certain vowel sound

239.40.text:
The sound that you get in 'fish and chips'
So we have

249.51.text:
Index finger
But these ones are different

253.05.text:
These are your thumbs
So I don't know

255.58.text:
Perhaps they're not fingers after all
Micro wave
